datafield.subfield: A validated methodology for the 3D reconstruction of cochlea geometries using human microCT images

Accurate reconstruction of the inner ear is a prerequisite for the modelling and understanding of the inner ear mechanics. In this study, we present a semi-automated methodology for accurate reconstruction of the major inner ear structures (scalae, basilar membrane, stapes and semicircular canals). For this purpose, high resolution microCT images of a human specimen were used. The segmentation methodology is based on an iterative level set algorithm which provides the borders of the structures of interest. An enhanced coupled level set method which allows the simultaneous multiple image labeling without any overlapping regions has been developed for this purpose. The marching cube algorithm was applied in order to extract the surface from the segmented volume. The reconstructed geometries are then post-processed to improve the basilar membrane geometry to realistically represent physiologic dimensions. The final reconstructed model is compared to the available data from the literature. The results show that our generated inner ear structures are in good agreement with the published ones, while our approach is the most realistic in terms of the basilar membrane thickness and width reconstruction.

i. Coupled level sets are applied with small \mu = 0.2, in order to allow fast growth of the level set interface and to detect small objects
ii. Morphological operations (filling holes and removing small areas) are applied in order to fill holes and remove small isolated regions
iii. Coupled level sets are applied with large \mu = 2, enforcing a smoother segmentation of the cochlea

i. Threshold initial volume (figure, 4(A): #mstaa5f18f04) to keep only bone regions (>6000 Hounsfield Unit (HU)). The threshold was estimated based on the HU histogram of the specific dataset in order to discriminate bone from other lesions in the area near the vestibule, however a more automated method [, 22: #mstaa5f18bib022] could be used
ii. Repeat a number (, 2: #mstaa5f18eqn002) of erosions and dilations. Then perform hole filling. The resulting volume ({{V}_{1}}) is the one containing the vestibule (figure, 4(B): #mstaa5f18f04)

iii. Threshold the initial volume (<5000 HU), let {{V}_{2}}, and calculate the intersection of {{V}_{1}} and {{V}_{2}}, let {{V}_{3}} (figure, 4(C): #mstaa5f18f04). The threshold was estimated based on the HU histogram of the specific dataset. This intersection removes pixels corresponding to bone and pixels outside the cochlea ROI

iv. Find the connected components of volume {{V}_{3}}. The identified connected components correspond to the different major cavities of the cochlea, the largest corresponding to the vestibule. Therefore, the largest connected component corresponds to the vestibule (figure, 4(D): #mstaa5f18f04)
ii. Level set initial mask selection for the two level sets corresponding to the two areas separated by the round window (figure, 5(A): #mstaa5f18f05)

iii. Application of the coupled Level (let {{R}_{1}} and {{R}_{2}}) with \mu = 0.2. The Euclidean distance transforms of {{R}_{1}} and {{R}_{2}} are calculated, let be D_{1}^{R} and D_{2}^{R} respectively
iv. The mask of the round window volume is given by:
where I(i,j,k) the intensity of voxel (i,j,k), {{t}_{\text{d}}} a distance threshold = 3 and {{t}_{\text{h}}} an HU threshold = 5000
i. Select volume ROI including the stapes (figure, 6(A): #mstaa5f18f06)

ii. Threshold image to extract a volume mask \text{S}{{\text{T}}_{0}} corresponding to bone regions. The threshold for the specific dataset was set to 7000 HU. The threshold was estimated based on the HU histogram of the specific dataset in order to discriminate bone from other lesions in the area near the stapes
iii. Perform a number of image erosions in order to separate the connected regions. For the specific dataset 3 erosion operators having a 3-3-3 mask was applied (figure, 6(B): #mstaa5f18f06)

iv. Find the connected components of the volume (figure, 6(C): #mstaa5f18f06, let \text{S}{{\text{T}}_{1}}. If the ROI selection is appropriate the largest connected component should correspond to the stapes. Otherwise, a user intervention may be needed

v. Perform a number of dilation operations in the volume (\text{S}{{\text{T}}_{1}}) in order to cover all the stapes area (\text{S}{{\text{T}}_{2}}). For the specific dataset 3 dilation operators with a 3-3-3 mask was applied. Find the intersection of \text{S}{{\text{T}}_{0}} and \text{S}{{\text{T}}_{2}}, let \text{S}{{\text{T}}_{3}}, with background voxels included by dilation, removed. Perform a dilation and an erosion operation on \text{S}{{\text{T}}_{3}} to remove very small components with a 3-3-3 mask (\left. \text{S}{{\text{T}}_{4}}\right). The result of this step is depicted in figure, 6(D): #mstaa5f18f06
vi. Again find the largest connected region \text{S}{{\text{T}}_{5}} which corresponds to the stapes (figure, 5(E): #mstaa5f18f05)
